org.sd.util
Class StringSplitter

java.lang.Object
  org.sd.util.StringSplitter

public class StringSplitter
extends java.lang.Object

Utilities for splitting strings various ways.

These methods are meant as helpers for segmenting strings in an I18N-safe way.

Author:
Spence Koehler

expand

public static java.lang.String expand(java.lang.String data,
                                      java.lang.String delim)
Expand (i.e. add delims between) the data according to the following rules. Where isLetter(x) == true and isDigit(d) == true, isUpper(u) == true, isLower(l) == true, add a space after periods (unless at end): x.x -> x. x set numbers off with spaces: xd -> x d; dx -> d x expand camel case: U+Ul -> U+ Ul; lU -> l U

splitOnChar

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnChar(java.lang.String data,
                                             char delim)
Split the data string into multiple strings based on the given delimiter.

splitOnFirstEquals

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnFirstEquals(java.lang.String data)
Split on the first equals found in the data.

If there is no equals to split on, return null.

For example: a=b will be split as "a", and "b". "a=b=c" will be split as "a", "b=c".

Parameters:
data - The data to split.
Returns:
null if the pattern is not found or an array of length 2 containing the data to the left of the equals in result[0] and the data to the right of the equals in result[1].

splitOnFirstSpace

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnFirstSpace(java.lang.String data)
Split the string on the first space, returning the data before the space in result[0] and the data after the space in result[1]. If there is no space in data (and the data is non-null and non-empty), return data in result[0].

splitOnFirstDelim

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnFirstDelim(java.lang.String data,
                                                   char delim)
Split on the first equals found in the data.

If there is no equals to split on, return null.

For example: a=b will be split as "a", and "b". "a=b=c" will be split as "a", "b=c".

Parameters:
data - The data to split.
delim - The delimiter to split on (i.e. '=').
Returns:
null if the pattern is not found or an array of length 2 containing the data to the left of the equals in result[0] and the data to the right of the equals in result[1].

splitOnSemis

public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> splitOnSemis(java.lang.String data)
Split on unescaped semicolons, where an escaped semicolon is one that does not appear in a construct "&...;".

For example, splitting "a;b;c" will yield {"a", "b", "c"}. Splitting "a&tag;b;c" will yield {"a&tag;b", "c"}.

Parameters:
data - The string to split.
Returns:
a List of Strings that includes the data between unescaped semicolons.

splitOnParens

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnParens(java.lang.String data)
Given a string of the form: "a(b)c", where b and/or c may include delimiters, but a does not include a left delimiter, return a native array of Strings with the three strings a, b, and c.

If there is not a set of balanced parentheses, null will be returned; otherwise, a, b, and c will be in the array (even if a, b, or c are empty) at indeces 0, 1, and 2, respectively.

Parameters:
data - The data to split.
Returns:
null if the pattern doesn not exist, or a String array of length exactly 3, where result[0] has data before the widest balanced delims, result[1] has data within the widest balanced delims (not including the delims themselves), and result[2] has data after the widest balances delims.

splitOnSquareBrackets

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnSquareBrackets(java.lang.String data)
Given a string of the form: "a[b]c", where b and/or c may include delimiters, but a does not include a left delimiter, return a native array of Strings with the three strings a, b, and c.

If there is not a set of balanced parentheses, null will be returned; otherwise, a, b, and c will be in the array (even if a, b, or c are empty) at indeces 0, 1, and 2, respectively.

Parameters:
data - The data to split.
Returns:
null if the pattern doesn not exist, or a String array of length exactly 3, where result[0] has data before the widest balanced delims, result[1] has data within the widest balanced delims (not including the delims themselves), and result[2] has data after the widest balances delims.

splitOnDelims

public static java.lang.String[] splitOnDelims(java.lang.String data,
                                               char leftDelim,
                                               char rightDelim)
Given a string of the form: "a(b)c", where b and/or c may include delimiters, but a does not include a left delimiter, return a native array of Strings with the three strings a, b, and c.

The delim char for '(' can be specified in the "leftDelim" parameter. The delim char for ')' can be specified in the "rightDelim" parameter.

If there is not a set of balanced parentheses, null will be returned; otherwise, a, b, and c will be in the array (even if a, b, or c are empty) at indeces 0, 1, and 2, respectively.

Parameters:
data - The data to split.
leftDelim - The delimiter character to use for the left.
rightDelim - The delimiter character to use for the right.
Returns:
null if the pattern doesn not exist, or a String array of length exactly 3, where result[0] has data before the widest balanced delims, result[1] has data within the widest balanced delims (not including the delims themselves), and result[2] has data after the widest balances delims.

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
                 throws java.io.IOException
Throws:
java.io.IOException
